Hi all,

I'm a grad student at Virginia Tech and I would like to enter a bo=
t
into the AAAI poker competition in July.  I've been working on poker
AI i=
n my spare time for the last 3 years.  I've looked at a lot of the
Alberta =
group's work and talked to most of them at last year's AAAI
competition.

M=
y general plan is to use KB-NEAT and a set of controllers + variables
to ev=
olve a network for rapid player modeling and exploitation in
limit (and pos=
sibly no-limit) Hold Em.

A lot of the knowledge in poker is very explicit =
with little
exceptions.  For instance, "cap with the nut flush" (i.e. never=
 stop
raising) is a perfect example of a piece of advice that works in 80%
=
of cases, but certain situations, like the board being paired,
invalidate t=
hat advice.  I hope to help kick-start the learning
process by developing a=
 fairly in-depth set of advice rules.

My bot will also deviate from the no=
rmal approach of game_state ->
atomic action (e.g., fold/call/raise).  Inst=
ead I'm going to have the
bot select a "play" at the start of each round.  =
I define a play as a
set of betting actions that handle any case in the cur=
rent round.  An
example post-flop play (from first position) would be
Check=
-Raise-Call.  Here, there is no way that the bot could ever reach
a situati=
on where it doesn't know what to do.

I chose to use plays for two reasons.=
  First, they simplify the input
to the network as you do not have to consi=
der the sequence of bets. 
Second, I believe that most (non-novice) human p=
layers actually use a
similar--or even higher level-- model when playing.  =
For instance,
good players no-limit players (and to a lesser extent, limit =
players)
will often play a single hand in a loose fashion (usually attempti=
ng a
large bluff), hoping that the next hand will give them a similar
situa=
tion but with a legitimate hand.  In such cases, players are
actually plann=
ing on making the bluffs and subsequent big hands well
ahead of time.  The =
evidence for this should be the speed with which
most limit ring games are =
played.  As the stakes rise, the speed of
the game tends to increase, as pl=
ayers create more abstract plays.

The inputs for my networks will be broke=
n down into three main
categories: betting, stats, and history.  Betting wi=
ll simply be a
represenation of the previous rounds' bet history.  Stats wi=
ll
encompass things like hand strength vs a random player, flush draw
proba=
bility, etc.

History will be a set of player statistics broken into 3
sub-=
categories: total, previous hand, and a variable range.  The
statistics for=
 each category will all be the same, with only the
sample size varying.  To=
tal will encompass the entire play history of
the opponent.  Previous hand =
will look only at the previous hand. 
Variable range will use the play over=
 the previous N hands (where N <
30).  This way I hope to be able to model =
players that quickly change
their play.

I have a few questions:

1) Is the=
re a way I can use multiple networks per individual in the
population?  I.e=
., I want to have a separate network for each round,
since there are differ=
ent inputs (cards, bets) for each successive
round.  I have considered maki=
ng one monolithic network and using
extra nodes to represent on/off status =
of the round-specific data, but
I feel like that would add a lot of needles=
s noise to the network.

2) This is related to 1, but is there any way to a=
lso encorporate
other variables in my evolution parameters?

3) Is there an=
y code available for the KB-NEAT so I can incorporate my
custom advice?

f anyone is interested in a more detailed description of the inputs,

 know.
